questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of intermittent loose stools and a 1.2-kg (2.6-lb) weight loss. She immigrated to the US from Uganda 6 weeks ago. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness with no guarding or rebound. The liver is firm and palpable 3 cm below the right costal margin, and the spleen is palpable just below the left costal margin. Her leukocyte count is 12,800/mm3 (12% eosinophils). A photomicrograph of a stool sample is shown. Microscopic examination of a liver biopsy specimen shows granulomatous inflammation with periportal fibrosis. Exposure to which of the following is most likely to have played a role in the development of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

African sleeping sickness is caused by Trypanosoma brucei infection, a parasite transmitted by the tsetse fly. Early in the course of this disease, non-specific symptoms such as intermittent fever, headaches, lymphadenopathy, and arthralgias are seen (hemolymphatic phase). Weeks to months later, invasion of the central nervous system may lead to confusion, coordination problems, and sleeping disorders (neurological phase), none of which are seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Trichinella spiralis can be transmitted by ingestion of larvae in undercooked pork meat, causing trichinellosis. After ingestion of contaminated meat, cysts release larvae in the stomach, causing gastrointestinal symptoms including abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea (enteral phase). Adult worms then migrate to muscles, where they encyst, causing myalgia (parenteral phase). Taenia solium can also be transmitted by the ingestion of larvae (cysticerci) in contaminated raw pork meat. Hepatosplenic involvement, as seen in this patient, would not be expected with either of these parasites. Schistosomiasis is not associated with undercooked pork.

C) INCORRECT:

Ingestion of undercooked freshwater fish is the mode of transmission of Diphyllobothrium latum and Clonorchis sinensis. Both types of infection can lead to nonspecific gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. Clonorchis sinensis infection can also affect the hepatobiliary tract and classically presents with cholelithiasis and cholangitis secondary to formation of brown pigment gallstones. However, the stool culture findings seen in this patient are not consistent with either of these pathogens and ingestion of freshwater fish is not associated with schistosomiasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Toxocara canis (dog roundworm) and Echinococcus granulosus (hydatid tapeworm) are two parasites that can be acquired by ingestion of eggs from the feces of an infected dog. Echinococcosis is classically a condition of the lungs and liver and presents with single or multiple hepatic hydatid cysts, which may lead to liver enlargement. Symptoms of toxocariasis include weight loss and hepatomegaly. However, the stool culture findings seen in this patient are not consistent with either of these pathogens and exposure to dog feces is not associated with schistosomiasis.

E) CORRECT:

Freshwater snails in endemic regions serve as the intermediate host for schistosomiasis. Parasitic larvae (cercariae) initially penetrate the skin and enter the circulation to mature, and eventually produce eggs that migrate through the venous system and can spread to the lungs, spleen, liver, brain, and/or bladder (depending on the species of Schistosoma). Intestinal and hepatosplenic involvement is commonly seen with Schistosoma mansoni or Schistosoma japonicum infection, while bladder involvement only occurs with Schistosoma haematobium. Unlike the eggs of S. mansoni and S. japonicum, which have a lateral spine and are shed via human feces, the eggs of S. haematobium have a terminal spine and are excreted in urine. S. mansoni is endemic to Africa and South America, S. japonicum to East Asia, and S. haematobium to Africa and the Middle East.

Treatment of schistosomiasis includes praziquantel. Steroids can be added to the treatment to relieve hypersensitivity reactions.
Image Description:

An infected human, the definitive host of schistosomes, excretes schistosome eggs in urine or feces (yellow and brown arrow). The eggs hatch in water and release miracidia. These flat, ciliated larva penetrate specific freshwater snails, which then act as intermediate hosts. In the snail, the miracidia develop into sporocysts, which reproduce asexually to form cercaria. Cercaria are then released back in the water. When humans come in contact with contaminated water, cercaria can penetrate the skin and enter the circulation. As they lose their tail, the cercaria develop into schistosomula, which then mature into adult schistosomes in the venous system. At this point, a male and female adult worm mate and migrate to the veins of the target organs (liver, intestine, bladder). The female worm lies folded in the longitudinal cleft (schist) of the male worm and lays eggs, which causes inflammation of the organs. As a result of the inflammation, the eggs can penetrate the wall of the organ and enter the lumen of the intestine or bladder (depending on the species), and they are then eliminated in feces or urine.
questions.hint: This patient has features suggestive of intestinal and hepatosplenic schistosomiasis. An oval-shaped egg with a prominent lateral spine is consistent with Schistosoma mansoni infection.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of increased urinary frequency for the past month. He has also noticed blood in the urine, usually towards the end of voiding. He immigrated to the US from Kenya 5 years ago. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Physical examination shows a palpable liver edge and splenomegaly. A urine dipstick is strongly positive for blood. A CT scan of the pelvis shows bladder wall thickening and fibrosis. Microscopic examination of a biopsy specimen of the bladder obtained during cystoscopy shows squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Calcified cysts in the liver parenchyma
Dilation of right and left ventricles

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with schistosomiasis develop portal hypertension as a result of obstruction of the portal venules and hepatic fibrosis but schistosomiasis does not typically cause hepatic cyst formation. Calcified hepatic cysts develop in patients with echinococcosis, a helminthic infection caused by Echinococcus granulosus or Echinococcus multilocularis. Echinococcosis can cause hepatomegaly and, in the case of E. multilocularis, portal hypertension but bladder involvement is not a typical manifestation of echinococcal disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic schistosomiasis can cause cor pulmonale and right ventricular hypertrophy but is not associated with dilated cardiomyopathy. Biventricular dilation, suggesting dilated cardiomyopathy, can occur as a complication of Chagas disease, which is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi and endemic to Central and South America, not Africa.

C) CORRECT:

Schistosoma haematobium is endemic to Africa and the Middle East and causes genitourinary schistosomiasis, which if left untreated can cause squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder. Hepatosplenic schistosomiasis, which results in presinusoidal portal hypertension, most commonly occurs with S. mansoni or S. japonicum infection but can also occur with S. haematobium infection. Pulmonary schistosomiasis is a common complication of hepatosplenic schistosomiasis. The development of portal hypertension precipitates the development of portosystemic shunts, which allow embolization of schistosome eggs into the pulmonary circulation, leading to granulomatous pulmonary endarteritis. This condition leads to irreversible pulmonary hypertension, elevated mean pulmonary artery pressure and, ultimately, cor pulmonale. Schistosomiasis is the most common parasitic disease associated with pulmonary hypertension.
Image Description:

Areas in which schistosomiasis (bilharzia) are endemic are highlighted. Clinical features depend on the type of Schistosoma. May manifest in urogenital, intestinal, or hepatosplenic form. On this map, hepatosplenic schistosomiasis is counted as intestinal schistosomiasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Schistosomiasis is not associated with these findings. Retinal atrophy, uveitis, and punctate or sclerosing keratitis are features of chronic onchocerciasis (river blindness), which is caused by infection with the parasitic worm Onchocerca volvulus. Other clinical manifestations of chronic onchocerciasis include subcutaneous nodules and pruritus. Bladder and hepatosplenic involvement are not typical features of onchocerciasis.

E) INCORRECT:

Portal hypertension or cor pulmonale due to schistosomiasis can cause pitting peripheral edema, not nonpitting edema. Nonpitting edema is a feature of lymphedema, which occurs in patients with chronic lymphatic filariasis as a result of lymphatic obstruction (often in the lower extremities). Bladder and hepatosplenic involvement are not typical features of filariasis.
questions.hint: In a patient with a history of immigration from an endemic region, hepatosplenic and bladder disease suggest chronic schistosomiasis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old Marine comes to the veterans’ administration outpatient clinic because of a 3-week history of pain on urination. The patient says that the pain has gotten gradually worse and that he has noticed a reddish hue in his urine, especially when he is almost done urinating. He returned from a deployment to Egypt 3 months ago, where he spent 6 months on a mission on the Nile. He has no personal history of serious illness. His father died of metastatic prostate cancer at 82 years of age. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily and does not drink alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urine dipstick shows 2+ blood, and urine microscopy shows parasitic eggs with a prominent terminal spine. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Praziquantel is the treatment of choice for chronic schistosomiasis. Praziquantel is only effective after the parasitic worms have matured, so it should be administered after symptoms of acute illness have resolved (approx. 4–6 weeks after the initial infection). In acute schistosomiasis syndrome (Katayama fever), praziquantel should only be administered after corticosteroids because it can trigger an immune reaction to released schistosome antigens. If left untreated, genitourinary schistosomiasis may lead to bladder neck obstruction and hydronephrosis, infertility (due to migration to internal genitalia; more common in women), and squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of urine concentrate (wet mount; 500× magnification)

An oval-shaped egg (green overlay) with a transparent shell (red outline), a small protrusion at one pole, and a sharp terminal spine (blue line) is pictured.

This is the characteristic microscopic appearance of a Schistosoma haematobium egg, which is excreted in the urine (or feces) of an infected host.

B) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is used to treat bacterial infections with anaerobes (e.g., Clostridioides difficile, Bacteroides spp.) and parasitic infections with certain protozoa (e.g., Entamoeba histolytica, Giardia lamblia, Trichomonas vaginalis). However, metronidazole is ineffective against schistosomiasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids such as prednisolone are the initial treatment for acute schistosomiasis syndrome (Katayama fever). This patient's urine microscopy findings confirm the diagnosis of schistosomiasis. However, acute schistosomiasis syndrome typically develops 3–8 weeks after initial exposure and manifests with fever, fatigue, cough, myalgia, and/or angioedema, none of which is seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Ivermectin is an antihelminthic drug used against onchocerciasis, strongyloidiasis, and hookworm infections (i.e., ancylostomiasis, necatoriasis). It is not indicated against chronic schistosomiasis.

E) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin is indicated in bacterial lower urinary tract infections, which typically manifest with dysuria and hematuria, both of which are seen here. However, ciprofloxacin does not have antihelminthic effects, so it is ineffective against Schistosoma haematobium.
questions.hint: This patient's urine microscopy shows parasitic eggs with a prominent terminal spine, a distinctive feature of Schistosoma haematobium, which is endemic to Africa and the Middle East. These findings in conjunction with the patient's clinical presentation (i.e., dysuria and hematuria) and travel history, make genitourinary schistosomiasis, a form of chronic schistosomiasis, the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman who recently emigrated from North Africa presents to the emergency department reporting a 3-day history of hematemesis. She is tachycardic but normotensive.
Physical examination reveals tender hepatomegaly but no evidence of chronic liver disease or ascites. A rectal examination reveals melena.
Laboratory testing documents a hematocrit of 25.0% (reference range, 36.0–46.0%), a mean corpuscular volume of 70 μm3 (80–100), and normal results for international normalized ratio, liver function, and total bilirubin.
The patient receives a transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells. A subsequent upper endoscopy reveals large esophageal varices with old blood in the stomach but no active bleeding.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most likely to identify the cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Right-upper-quadrant Doppler ultrasonography is used to diagnose Budd-Chiari syndrome, but a typical presentation includes acute abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and ascites.

B) INCORRECT:

The lack of stigmata of chronic liver disease suggests that hepatocyte function is unaffected; this is typical of schistosomiasis but would be inconsistent with both hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, which is very prevalent in North Africa and Southeast Asia, and hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection. Although portal hypertension can occur in HBV and HCV infections, it is a late complication and would always be associated with hepatocyte dysfunction and stigmata of chronic liver disease.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with evidence of portal hypertension (esophageal varices) in the absence of any stigmata of chronic liver disease. This finding, when coupled with a history of time spent in North Africa, is most consistent with schistosomiasis, a disease that affects nearly 200 million people worldwide, mostly in Africa. Trapped eggs from schistosomes can lead to granulomatous inflammation of the periportal spaces, which can progress to fibrosis and lead to occlusion of the portal veins. The most appropriate diagnostic test is a stool ova and parasites test for schistosomiasis.

The lack of stigmata of chronic liver disease suggests that hepatocyte function is unaffected; this is typical of schistosomiasis but would be inconsistent with both hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, which is very prevalent in North Africa and Southeast Asia, and hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection. Although portal hypertension can occur in HBV and HCV infections, it is a late complication and would always be associated with hepatocyte dysfunction and stigmata of chronic liver disease.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of portal hypertension in a patient with normal liver function who recently emigrated from North Africa is schistosomiasis.

D) INCORRECT:

The lack of stigmata of chronic liver disease suggests that hepatocyte function is unaffected; this is typical of schistosomiasis but would be inconsistent with both hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, which is very prevalent in North Africa and Southeast Asia, and hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection. Although portal hypertension can occur in HBV and HCV infections, it is a late complication and would always be associated with hepatocyte dysfunction and stigmata of chronic liver disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Echinococcal infection is possible, although it is typically accompanied by elevated aminotransferase levels, jaundice, and fever.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman is seen for her annual physical examination. Her travel history is significant for a 6-week business trip to Uganda, from which she returned 3 months ago. The majority of her time was spent in meetings in an urban locale. She took malaria prophylaxis and received all the recommended pretravel vaccines. She stayed in a reputable hotel and never walked around barefoot. On her last weekend there, she went on a rafting trip on the Nile River.
She reports that she had flulike symptoms of fevers, myalgias, headache, and dry cough 2 weeks after returning home that subsequently resolved after 4 to 5 days. Otherwise, she has been feeling well. She asks whether she should be checked for parasites.
Given her freshwater exposure on her trip, which one of the following parasites could she be infected with?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ascariasis happens after individuals eat eggs or contaminated food and is not transmitted in freshwater.

B) INCORRECT:

Filarial worms are not transmitted in freshwater but by insects.

C) INCORRECT:

Trichinella is found in undercooked pork and is not transmitted in freshwater.

D) CORRECT:

Schistosomiasis is an infection caused by a trematode worm. Schistosoma mansoni, Schistosoma haematobium, and Schistosoma intercalatum are all found in sub-Saharan Africa. Certain snail species are the intermediate hosts and release an immature form of the worm into the water; the worm can then penetrate human skin. Although immediate symptoms such as rash and urticaria can occur, most infections are asymptomatic. Acute schistosomiasis, also called Katayama fever, usually begins an average of 2 to 6 weeks (up to 84 days) after contact with infested water; it causes fever, headaches, myalgias, dry cough, and eosinophilia. The adult worm can live in the human body for years. Chronic pathology can result from the deposition of eggs into the liver, genitourinary tract, and intestines. For example, symptoms can be intestinal (abdominal pain or diarrhea), genitourinary (dysuria or hematuria), or hepatic (dyspepsia or abdominal discomfort).

Key learning point: Freshwater exposure in many areas of sub-Saharan Africa increases the risk of schistosomiasis.

E) INCORRECT:

Hookworm infection happens after people walk barefoot on contaminated soil and is not transmitted in freshwater.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old woman reports a 3-day history of dysuria that is worse toward the end of urination. She also reports increased urinary frequency and an occasional pinkish discoloration in the toilet-bowl water. She states that she does not experience fever, chills, or diarrhea. Her medical history is notable for hypertension managed with lisinopril. Four months ago, she traveled to East Africa for a kayaking trip, where she experienced flulike symptoms that lasted approximately 2 weeks. A urine dipstick test is positive for blood; urine culture is negative for bacterial growth.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this case?

choices.text: Microscopic examination of three separate samples of urine on different days
Stool testing for ova and parasites

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Dysuria in a middle-aged woman usually suggests uncomplicated cystitis; however, this patient was exposed to fresh water in an area endemic to Schistosoma haematobium, raising the likelihood of this infection.

Schistosoma haematobium infestation occurs when cercariae penetrate the skin. During the acute phase, flulike symptoms may occur; this syndrome is known as Katayama fever. Mature worms lay ova in the perivesical venous plexi; the ova can penetrate the bladder lining. Depending on the worm and ova burden, patients can be asymptomatic or have dysuria and hematuria, both of which are typically worse at the end of urination, when the bladder contracts maximally. The diagnosis is made by microscopy and by identifying the characteristic ova in the urine.

Schistosoma shed more ova midday, so a noon-time specimen collection is ideal. Three urine samples should be collected on different days to increase the sensitivity of testing. The treatment is typically a single dose of praziquantel timed at least 8 weeks after the last exposure to potentially contaminated fresh water.

Serologic testing for schistosomiasis is also an option when considering this diagnosis. Of note, the tests generally take 6 to 12 weeks to turn positive (so they may be negative during acute infection), and a positive serologic test does not indicate the site of infection. In this case, it would be reasonable to send serologic testing as an adjunct to the urine microscopy.

Key learning point: In a patient exposed to fresh water in tropical or subtropical Africa, an infectious cause of dysuria and hematuria is Schistosoma haematobium.

B) INCORRECT:

Radiograph of the pelvis may detect urinary tract calcifications, but this finding is not specific.

C) INCORRECT:

Stool testing for ova and parasites is not indicated in a patient with dysuria unless the patient has gastrointestinal symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Thick and thin blood smears are used to diagnose malaria, which does not cause dysuria.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients with Schistosoma haematobium infection, cystoscopy may identify small fibrotic nodules that develop from deposition of eggs and subsequent granulomas; these are known as “sandy patches.” Cystoscopy would be appropriate if the cause of hematuria and dysuria could not be determined by urinalysis, culture, or examination of concentrated urine.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who is an aid worker presents with a 5-day history of fever, fatigue, dry cough, and facial swelling. She returned from rural Ghana 4 weeks ago, where she was with fishermen on Lake Volta. Physical examination shows mild hepatosplenomegaly, and laboratory studies show eosinophilia with elevated IgE levels. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While infectious disease consultation may be helpful for complex disease, it is not the most immediate priority.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Prednisone therapy is the most appropriate initial treatment for acute schistosomiasis syndrome. The combination of fever, fatigue, cough, angioedema, and eosinophilia following freshwater exposure in an endemic area is consistent with acute schistosomiasis syndrome. Glucocorticoids reduce the inflammatory response from immune complex formation, and praziquantel is given later, once inflammation subsides.

C) INCORRECT:

Supportive care alone is insufficient for acute schistosomiasis syndrome. While the condition may self-resolve in 2–10 weeks, active anti-inflammatory treatment with glucocorticoids is indicated to reduce symptoms and prevent complications.

D) INCORRECT:

Antihistamines are not appropriate for acute schistosomiasis syndrome. While this patient's presentation includes eosinophilia and angioedema that might suggest an allergic reaction, acute schistosomiasis syndrome is a serum sickness-like inflammatory condition caused by immune complex formation. Antihistamines do not address the underlying inflammatory pathophysiology.

E) INCORRECT:

Immediate praziquantel therapy is contraindicated in acute schistosomiasis syndrome because it may exacerbate the serum sickness-like symptoms by increasing circulating schistosome antigens. Praziquantel should be administered only after inflammation improves with glucocorticoid therapy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with a 4-day history of fever, myalgia, and nonproductive cough. The patient returned from a volunteer trip to Lake Volta in rural Ghana 6 weeks ago. Physical examination shows mild periorbital edema and no rash. Vital signs are normal. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis with 12% eosinophils. Stool analysis shows eggs with a prominent terminal spine. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge with symptomatic care and primary care follow-up

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has acute schistosomiasis syndrome based on the timeline (3–8 weeks post-freshwater exposure), clinical features (fever, myalgia, cough, angioedema), and eosinophilia. Initial treatment involves systemic corticosteroids to reduce inflammation, followed by praziquantel therapy once inflammation improves.

B) INCORRECT:

While acute schistosomiasis syndrome may be self-limited, active treatment with systemic corticosteroids is recommended to reduce inflammation and prevent complications. Discharge without treatment is inappropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is indicated for certain protozoa (Entamoeba histolytica, Giardia duodenalis, Trichomonas vaginalis) and anaerobic bacteria, but it has no activity against helminths such as schistosomes.

D) INCORRECT:

Antihistamines are not appropriate for acute schistosomiasis syndrome. While this patient's presentation includes eosinophilia and angioedema that might suggest an allergic reaction, acute schistosomiasis syndrome is a serum sickness-like inflammatory condition caused by immune complex formation. Antihistamines do not address the underlying inflammatory pathophysiology and are insufficient to manage this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Immediate praziquantel therapy is contraindicated in acute schistosomiasis syndrome because it may worsen serum sickness-like symptoms by increasing circulating schistosome antigens and inflammatory response.
